title-group.article-title: Study on constructional design and structural analysis of poly(amide-imide)/ZnO nanocomposites containing pyromellitoyl-bis-l-isoleucine moieties

article-meta.aff: 1Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran
2Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Institute, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Shadpour Mallakpour, Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84156-83111, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: mallak@cc.iut.ac.ir

abstract.p: Hybrid nanocomposites (NCs) produced by the dispersion of zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles (NPs) in thermoplastic poly(amide-imide)s (PAIs) are designed and synthesized using ultrasonic-assisted technology. ZnO NPs were functionalized with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (KH550) coupling agent to increase the hydrophobic nature of NPs. Reaction of diamine containing N-(4-hydroxyphenyl) benzamide and a diacid chloride comprising pyromellitoyl-bis-l-isoleucine segments at low temperature provided the polymeric matrix with well-designed groups. Surface treatments of ZnO NPs gave a better dispersion and enhancing possible interactions of NPs with functional units of polymer matrix. The surface-modified ZnO NPs were dispersed uniformly in the PAIs matrix using ultrasonic irradiation. The obtained NCs were characterized by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, x-ray powder diffraction, atomic force microscopy, field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and thermogravimetry analysis. The FE-SEM and TEM pictures confirmed the globular-like structures for NCs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The nanoscopic scale in science and engineering is a thrilling subject for both the fundamental interests and their practical aspects.1 Recently, the opening up of a new prospect by importing the nanoparticles (NPs) to organic polymers to create new nanocomposites (NCs) has attracted great interest. The preparation of organic–inorganic NCs suggests a suitable way to improve the physical properties of usual polymer and composite.2–8

Zinc oxide (ZnO) is a II-VI compound semiconductor with a wide direct band gap of about 3.3 eV at room temperature. ZnO is currently used in various applications, such as light-emitting diodes and in solar cells. Furthermore, ZnO-based NCs have been attracting considerable attention because NPs possess a large surface-to-volume ratio. The interaction between ZnO NPs and the surrounding materials can thus strongly affect the physical properties of NPs, offering a valuable means in engineer applications.9 In recent years, preparation of polymers hybridized with metallic oxides created an innovative field of active research for different applications due to the unique combination of advantageous properties of each of the components.10,11 In fact, the properties of hybrid materials are extensively relying on the situation of inorganic NPs, particle size, distribution and dispersion homogeneity over the entire matrix.

Different kinds of polymers such as polyurethanes,12 polyamides13 and polyimides (PIs) 14 were mainly used for the preparation of NCs. Due to the complementary balance between properties and functional groups, poly(amide-imide)s (PAIs) being a hopeful matrix nominee for the preparation of NCs. The thermally stable polymers that contain the optical active moieties showed great interest. The optically active polymers can be created by introduction of the chiral units in polymer structures such as using natural amino acids as linkages15–18 to comportment of extra benefits compulsory for some application areas such as in separation or catalyst sciences.

A primary problem in factual NPs application is that, it is particularly difficult to keep dispersions of NPs sturdy. Techniques such as high shear homogenization have been used commercially for deaggregation, while power ultrasound has been demonstrated to be a perfect option for this point. Power ultrasound is an inexpensive means of generating cavitations for emulsification, and it is relatively easy to scale-up. Robust ultrasonic wave irradiations can split bulky particles or particle aggregates into smaller particles. Such effects will diminish the particle size and also increase the reactivity in solution.19,20 In addition, surface-modified NPs with different molecules have attracted lots of consciousness over many years due to the new properties such as biocompatibility of surfaces and improved physical and chemical properties.21 NPs coating via the sol–gel process is generally performed using metal alkoxide precursors. Silicon alkoxide has been extensively studied not only as silica layers offer the opportunity to fabricate NCs with adapted physical properties but also because such moderately inert outside layer may be applied in order to keep NCs away from probable aggregation in their application situation and or coupling to other functional groups in matrix substrates.22,23 Hsu et al. have developed in situ formation of polymer-ZnO hybrid materials using two dianhydrides and a diamine for matrix preparation and 3-trimethoxysilylpropylmethacrylate as the stabilizing agent to prevent the aggregation of the ZnO NPs24 and, very recently, nano ZnO/hyperbranched PI hybrid film have been successfully synthesized by Gao and co-workers.25 We have focused on the synthesis of different kinds of polycondensation polymers and applications of them as matrices for NC preparations.26–28 Among the prepared polymers, PAIs due to the favorable balance of functionality and properties seem to be better candidate for NC technologies.

By prolonging our research activities in the field of optically active materials herein, we hope to report the design, synthesis and characterization of novel NCs using optically active PAIs derived from l-isoleucine amino acid and surface-modified ZnO NPs by means of ultrasonic supported technique. The morphology of the prepared NCs was characterized by atomic force microscopy (AFM), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The thermal properties of these NCs were also inspected and stated herein.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: ZnO nano powder was obtained from Neutrino Co. (Tehran, Iran) with average particle sizes of 25–30 nm. N,N-dimethylacetamide was dried over Barium oxide and then distilled in vacuum. The silane coupling agent 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (KH550), l-isoleucine and benzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic dianhydride were obtained from Merck Chemical Co. (Frankfurt, Germany) and were used as obtained without further purification.

The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a spectrophotometer (Jasco-680, Tokyo, Japan). The spectra of solids were obtained using Potassium bromide pellets. The vibrational transition frequencies are reported in wave numbers (cm−1). Band intensities are assigned as weak (w), medium (m), shoulder (sh), strong (s) and broad (br). Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) data for polymer and NCs were taken on a STA503 WinTA instrument in a nitrogen atmosphere at a rate of 10°C/min. The powder x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the polymer and NCs were recorded using a Philips X'PERT MPD (Germany) with a copper target at 40 kV and 35 mA and Cu Kα λ = 1.54 Å in the range of 10–80° at the speed of 0.05 min. AFM topographic images were obtained using digital multimode instruments nanoscope III (Digital Instrument Inc., USA) with noncontact tapping mode with a silica probe (NSC 11), a frequency of 463 kHz and using the Gwyddion 2.9 software. A TEM (Philips CM 120 operating at 100 kV) was used to observe the morphologies of NCs. FE-SEM was acquired by JSM-6700S Japan.

sec.title: Monomer synthesis
sec.p: N,N′-(Pyromellitoyl)-bis-l-isoleucine diacid chloride,29 3,5-Diamino-N-(4-hydroxyphenyl) benzamide30 and optically active PAIs were produced according to our previous studies.31

sec.title: Surface modification of ZnO NPs
sec.p: ZnO NPs were dehydrated at 120°C in an oven for 12 h to eliminate the adsorbed water. The 0.40 g dried nano ZnO was sonicated for 20 min in absolute ethanol and then 15 wt% of KH550 to NPs was added to the system and sonicated for 20 min. Obtained complex was separated and desiccated at 60°C for more than 20 h.

sec.title: Manufacture of PAIs/ZnO NCs
sec.p: The 0.10 g of PAI was dispersed in 20 mL of absolute ethanol. A homogeneous dispersion was obtained after sonication for 15 min. The suspension was combined with the appropriate amount of modified ZnO NPs to make 4, 8 and 12 wt% based on the PAI content. The resulting mixture was sonicated for 4 h. At the end, the solvent was separated and the collected solid eluted twice with ethanol and then dehydrated at 80°C for 2 h.

sec.title: Surface alteration of ZnO NPs
sec.p: The grafting illustration of ZnO NPs using KH550 is shown in Figure 1. The alkoxyl groups of KH550, silane coupling agent were hydrolyzed to form new silanol units. These newly formed silanol groups may condense to the hydroxyl groups which exist on the surface of the ZnO NPs. Displacement of some of the hydroxyl groups of ZnO NPs causes the creation of O–Si bonds in the surface of NPs. As indicated by the FT-IR spectra in Figure 2(a) and (b), the surface of the ZnO NPs was successfully modified by KH550. In the spectrum of pure ZnO (Figure 2(a)), the absorption bands at 3434 cm−1 designated as hydroxyl groups on the structure of NPs. The appearance of peaks at 1577, 1423 and 1065 cm−1 are attributed to the vibration of Zn–O bond. Also the peak positioned at 424 cm−1 is the distinctive absorption of Zn–O bond.

caption.p: Pictorial illustration of the preparation design of surface-modified ZnO NPs. ZnO: zinc oxide; NPs: nanoparticles.

FT-IR spectra of (a) net ZnO NPs, (b) surface-treated ZnO NPs, (c) PAI matrix, (d) NC (4 wt%), (e) NC (8 wt%) and (f) NC (12 wt%). FT-IR: Fourier-transform infrared; ZnO: zinc oxide; NPs: nanoparticles; PAI: poly(amide-imide); NC: nanocomposites.

sec.title: Design of organic–inorganic NCs derived from PAIs and ZnO NPs
sec.p: The PAIs are classified as thermally stable polymers with amide and imide functional groups. Also obliging of different functional units in the structure of prepared PAIs will help in the uniform dispersion of NPs in the production of NCs. The assembly of the PAIs and the possible interaction with surface-treated ZnO is shown in Figure 3. The 4, 8 and 12 wt% of ZnO NPs were introduced in PAI matrix. The sonication in absolute ethanol caused the deaggregation of the polymer particles and uniform distribution of inorganic species in the polymer matrix. Interactions such as physical van der Waals forces and the hydrogen bonding could be responsible for the constitution of NCs.

caption.p: Schematic design of the PAIs/ZnO NCs. PAIs: poly(amide-imide)s; ZnO: zinc oxide; NCs: nanocomposites.

sec.title: FT-IR spectra
sec.p: The FT-IR measurements were performed to assess the boundary affinity between PAIs and ZnO NPs. FT-IR spectra of the PAIs/ZnO NCs (4, 8 and 12 wt%) are shown in Figure 2(d) to (f), respectively. In the structure of PAIs, absorption bands related to amide, imide, hydroxyl, aromatic and aliphatic units were observed. The characteristic vibration band at 1661 was assigned to the amide units. The peak positions at 1775 and 1721 cm−1 are related to imide ring stretching. The peaks at 2923 and 2854 cm−1 are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of C–H bonds, respectively.

In Figure 2(d) to (f), all the NCs exhibit the characteristic absorption peaks of amide (1659 cm−1), imide (1772, 1719, 1380 and 728 cm−1), aromatic (3051 cm−1) and aliphatic groups (2953 and 2854 cm−1). The spectra of the NCs clearly exhibit the characteristic absorption peaks corresponding to polymeric groups with little displacements. With increasing the ZnO contents in NCs, the intensity of the absorption band at 424 cm−1 was altered. Due to the C–O and aliphatic C–H in PAI structure, strong absorption bands that appeared in 1090 cm−1 and 2927 cm−1, the characteristic peak of Si–O stretching related to organic modifier vibrations close to 1078 cm−1, were not noticeable in NCs, but they were observable in the structure of modified ZnO spectrum. Due to the hydrogen bonds, short-ranged steric and electrical interaction between surface-modified ZnO and different functional groups of PAIs, the characteristic functional group peaks of these NCs are shifted toward lower wave numbers in comparison to that of the pure PAIs.

sec.title: X-Ray diffraction pattern analysis
sec.p: The XRD patterns of PAIs and the PAI/ZnO NC 8 wt% after 2-h sonication are given in Figure 4(a) and (b), respectively. As can be seen in Figure 4, pure PAI powder represents the amorphous structure that showed broad diffraction peak gained based on its XRD pattern and remains with no changes during all of the sonication time. Peaks positioned at 2θ values 31.7, 34.5, 36.1, 47.6, 56.5, 62.8, 66.3, 67.8 and 69.2 were detected, respectively, which were in good agreement with the zincite phase of ZnO (International Center for Diffraction Data, JCPDS 5-0664). The results indicate that the ZnO NPs consisted of pure phase and no characteristic peaks for other impurity. The average crystallite size D was calculated by the Debye–Scherrer equation (D=Kλβcos⁡θ), where K is the Scherrer constant, λ is the x-ray wavelength, β is the peak width at half-maximum and θ is the Bragg diffraction angle. From the Debye–Scherrer calculation, the crystalline diameter was in the range of 28–35 nm. Also Figure 4 indicated that the morphology of ZnO NPs has not been changed during the process. An enormously broad peak were observed in the range of 2θ = 15–30° due to the amorphous nature of PAI matrix in the NCs structures.

caption.p: XRD diffraction patterns of (a) PAIs and (b) NCs (8 wt%). XRD: x-ray diffraction; PAIs: poly(amide-imide)s; NCs: nanocomposites.

sec.title: Morphological observation
sec.p: To find out the morphology of NCs more clearly, the TEM analysis was accomplished. TEM pictures of NC 8 wt% ZnO are presented in Figure 5. With decreasing surface energy, the aggregation between the NPs also decreased drastically. Most of the particles are distributed separately as shown in the TEM micrographs. The obtained results proved the identical dispersion of modified ZnO NPs in PAI matrix with the average particle size below than 40 nm. Direct evidence showed that the KH550 as a coupling agent and/or separator between NPs and ultrasonic waves have imperative functions in dispersing the NPs in polymeric matrix.

caption.p: TEM micrographs of NCs (8 wt%). TEM: transmission electron microscopy; NCs: nanocomposites.

sec.p: Figure 6 shows the FE-SEM analysis results for PAI/ZnO NC 4%wt. As can be seen, NC powder consisted of very fine and semiglobular particles. These particles have a mean diameter below than 50 nm and generally have fine edges. FE-SEM micrographs of different contents of ZnO NP samples show similar patterns, which demonstrated a uniform nanostructure inorganic moieties in the polymeric matrix and confirmed that the ZnO NPs are presented in nanoscale in NC structure.

caption.p: FE-SEM micrographs of NCs (4 wt%). FE-SEM: field-emission scanning electron microscopy; NCs: nanocomposites.

sec.p: The discovery of the AFM has offered new chances for obtaining three-dimensional high-resolution images under ambient conditions to study the surfaces of materials like NCs. Surface morphology the two and three dimension AFM images of the PAIs and the PAIs/ZnO NCs (8 wt%) are illustrated in Figure 7(a) to (d). For the preparation of samples, a composite powder was suspended in ethanol. Then a drop of it was poured on a glass plate and was placed under vacuum. The surface roughness value of the PAIs/ZnO NCs with 8 wt% modified ZnO NPs was estimated to be about 2.2 nm for the root mean square roughness and about 4.6 nm for the average surface roughness over a length span of 4.3 μm, respectively. It appeared that with introducing the ZnO NPs in polymer matrix, the hills of surface due to the residual of ZnO NPs in the surface were increased. Based on the analysis of the micrographs, it can be seen that the ZnO NPs with sizes of around 30 nm are well dispersed, which is steady with the results obtained from TEM.

caption.p: The two and three dimension AFM topography images of PAIs/ZnO NCs (8 wt%). AFM: atomic force microscopy; PAIs: poly(amide-imide)s; ZnO: zinc oxide; NCs: nanocomposites.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows the two-dimensional (a, d) plot of height versus measuring length (b, e) and height distribution profile (c, f) graphs in selected zones for PAI and NC 8 wt%, respectively. Four strands in the PAIs and three traverses in NC surface were selected. The selected length for analysis of surface in the case of PAIs and NCs were 13 and 4.5 μm, respectively. Graph (b) of Figure 8 illustrated that the height profiles in selected strands for PAIs were uniform and nearly smooth, but height profiles for NC 8 wt% showed different patterns of peaks and valleys in drawn span. By inspection, we can find symmetrical distribution of peaks and valleys from the central position in graph (b) for PAIs, while the peaks and valleys patterns from the middle line for NC 8 wt% showed asymmetrical distribution in graph (e). This may be related to the residual of NPs in surfaces, but in most location it showed similar patterns of peaks and valleys for NCs. Comparing Figure 8(c) and (f) related to the PAI and the PAI/ZnO NC 8 wt%, markedly different height distributions was identified. The maximum height density for PAIs was measured around 17 nm, while this value for NCs 8 wt% was positioned around 30–40 nm, which may be related to the approximate uniform distribution of NPs in the structure of NCs.

caption.p: Selected zones from two-dimensional AFM image (a, c) the plotted height profile across the measuring length (b, e) and the height distribution profiles (c, f). AFM: atomic force microscopy.

sec.title: Thermal analysis of PAI NCs
sec.p:
The thermal behavior and stability of the PAIs and PAIs/ZnO NCs were investigated using TGA method in N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C/min by decreasing weight of polymer and NCs versus increase in the temperature. The initial weight loss temperature for 0, 5 and 10%, for NCs at 800°C were in the range of 340–360°C, 434–460°C and 471–485°C, respectively. TGA data showed that PAIs are thermally stable up to 330°C (Figure 9). The data revealed high thermal stability of the obtained NCs, which mainly resulted from contribution of inorganic NPs to the polymeric matrix backbone. In addition, it can be seen from Figure 9 that the decomposition temperatures for 5% and 10% weight loss in PAIs/ZnO NCs are shifted to a higher temperature range, compared with that of pure PAIs, which indicates the enhancement of thermal stability of the composites. These thermal behaviors of the composites provided strong hydrogen bonding of PAI functional groups with the surface of modified ZnO particles. Also LOI values calculated based on van Krevelen and Hoftyzer equation.32Figure 9.
TGA thermograms of PAIs and PAIs/ZnO NCs with 4, 8 and 12 wt% ZnO contents. TGA: thermogravimetry analysis; PAIs: poly(amide-imide)s; ZnO: zinc oxide; NCs: nanocomposites.1LOI=17.5+0.4CR
where CR = char yield.

Thermal behaviors of the NCs were determined as a function of nano ZnO content up to 12 wt%. Increasing in the thermal stability may be related to the presence of ZnO network and the physical interactions of the ZnO NPs with PAI functional groups, which restricted the movement of the molecular chain of polymer. The char yield of pure PAIs at 800°C was 48%, while those of the NCs (4, 8 and 12 wt%) at 800°C were in the range of 51–56%. The values of LOI for NCs were in the range of 38–40, all the NCs can be categorized as the self-extinguishing materials.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Ultrasonic irradiation made it possible that the surface-modified ZnO NPs are uniformly dispersed in PAI matrix. This is related to the superior energy of sonication process that made higher temperature in the reaction media, which caused to increase the condensation reaction of surface-modified NPs and pendant hydroxyl units in the structure of PAIs. Due to the different functional groups in the structure of PAIs and functionalization of ZnO NPs with KH550. It can be estimated that the NPs homogenously dispersed in NCs. Also editing the surface of ZnO by incorporating the KH550 caused to introduce organic useful groups on the surface of NPs, which improved their compatibility and better dispersion of ZnO NPs in polymer matrix. The data obtained from FT-IR spectroscopy showed the existence of characteristic absorption bands related to ZnO NPs in the NCs structures. XRD diffraction patterns supported the information obtained from spectroscopic analysis. The morphological studies using AFM, FE-SEM and TEM images of NCs revealed that ZnO NPs were homogeneously dispersed in the macromolecule matrix.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: We also extend our thanks to IUT central laboratory staff for their valuable instrumental supports.

fn.p: This work was partially supported by the Research Affairs Division Isfahan University of Technology (IUT), Isfahan.
